questions.text: Which amongst the following is haploid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Spermatozoa

 

Explanation:

 

 

Diploid (2n):

 

  • Spermatogonia/ Oogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte/ Primary oocyte
  • Zygote

 

Haploid (n)

 

  • Secondary spermatocyte/ Secondary oocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Oocyte/ Spermatozoa

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the process of spermatogenesis and oogenesis, remember the following: 

 

Diploid (2n):

 

  • Spermatogonia/ Oogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte/ Primary oocyte
  • Zygote

 

Haploid (n)

 

  • Secondary spermatocyte/ Secondary oocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Oocyte/ Spermatozoa

 

Ref: Page no 15, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: The Neonatal period

questions.text: The onset of oogenesis starts during:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fetal period

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the female gonad, the germ cells undergo a number of rapid mitotic divisions and differentiate into oogonia
  • The number of oogonia reaches its maximum at the 20th week (about 7 million)
  • Majority of oogonia continue to divide
  • Some oogonia enter into the 1st meiotic division and are called primary oocytes
  • At birth, no more mitotic division and all oogonia are replaced by primary oocytes. (about 2 million)
  • 1st meiotic division is completed at puberty

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the female gonad, the germ cells undergo a number of rapid mitotic divisions and differentiate into oogonia
  • The number of oogonia reaches its maximum at the 20th week (about 7 million)
  • Majority of oogonia continue to divide
  • Some oogonia enter into the 1st meiotic division and are called primary oocytes
  • At birth, no more mitotic division and all oogonia are replaced by primary oocytes. (about 2 million)
  • 1st meiotic division is completed at puberty

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Follicles undergo meiosis in the fetal ovary
Oogenesis involves unequal division of cells
Oogonia get arrested in prophase 1
The number of oocytes are maximum at birth

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about oogenesis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oogenesis involves unequal division of cells

 

Option B: 

 

Oogenesis involves unequal division of cells with the end result being a secondary oocyte and 2 polar bodies

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Follicles undergo meiosis in the fetal ovary: Follicles do not undergo meiosis. The primary oocyte begins to undergo meiosis 1 in the fetal ovary but is arrested at prophase 1

 

Option C: Oogonia get arrested in prophase 1: The primary oocyte gets arrested in prophase 1 

 

Option D: The number of oocytes are maximum at birth: The maximum number of oocytes are at 20 weeks of fetal life (6-7 million)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref:  Page no 15, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: The maximum number of oocytes are at birth
Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase 1 of meiosis
The 1st polar body is formed at ovulation
Secondary oocytes are haploid

questions.text: All are true regarding oogenesis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The maximum number of oocytes are at birth

 

Explanation:

 

  • Max oogonia are at the 20th week of fetal life (7 million)
    • These reduce (by atresia and apoptosis) to 1-2 million at birth
    • 300-400,000 at puberty
    • 100 at menopause
    • Only 400-500 primary oocytes are likely to ovulate during the reproductive life of a woman
  • The oogonia enter meiosis to form the primary oocyte which rest in the diplotene phase of prophase 1 until puberty
  • Ovulation occurs just after meiosis 1 is complete resulting in a secondary oocyte and the 1st polar body
  • Meiosis 2 is completed at fertilization resulting in the female pro-nucleus and the 2nd polar body
  • Oogonia and primary oocytes are diploid
  • Secondary oocytes, ovum and polar bodies are haploid

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Max oogonia are at the 20th week of fetal life (7 million)
    • These reduce (by atresia and apoptosis) to 1-2 million at birth
    • 300-400,000 at puberty
    • 100 at menopause
    • Only 400-500 primary oocytes are likely to ovulate during the reproductive life of a woman
  • The oogonia enter meiosis to form the primary oocyte which rest in the diplotene phase of prophase 1 until puberty
  • Ovulation occurs just after meiosis 1 is complete resulting in a secondary oocyte and the 1st polar body
  • Meiosis 2 is completed at fertilization resulting in the female pro-nucleus and the 2nd polar body
  • Oogonia and primary oocytes are diploid
  • Secondary oocytes, ovum and polar bodies are haploid

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: The maturation and division of spermatogonia to spermatozoa takes:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 60 days

 

Explanation:

 

Spermatogenesis

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spermatogenesis takes 60-64 days and occurs in the seminiferous tubules.

 

Ref: Page no 17, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: The secondary oocyte and the 2nd polar body
The secondary oocyte and the 1st polar body
Two polar bodies
Two secondary oocytes

questions.text: The primary oocyte divides into:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The secondary oocyte and the 1st polar body

 

Explanation:

 

Oogenesis

 

 

  • Meiosis 1 (just before ovulation) results in the formation of secondary oocyte and the 1st polar body
  • Meiosis 2 (at the time of fertilization) results in the formation of the mature oocyte (female pronucleus) and the 2nd polar body

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th edition

questions.text: Match the following correctly:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1b 2b 3a 4a

 

Explanation:

 

 

Diploid (2n):

 

  • Spermatogonia/ Oogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte/ Primary oocyte
  • Zygote

 

Haploid (n):

 

  • Secondary spermatocyte/ Secondary oocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Oocyte/ Spermatozoa

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diploid (2n):

 

  • Spermatogonia/ Oogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte/ Primary oocyte
  • Zygote

 

Haploid (n):

 

  • Secondary spermatocyte/ Secondary oocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Oocyte/ Spermatozoa

 

Ref: Page no 15, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is undergoing IVF-ET. She has been explained that the embryo transfer will take place at the blastocyst stage. On what day after in vitro fertilization will this happen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Day 5

 

Explanation:

 

  • Blastocyst formation takes place on day 5
     

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Blastocyst formation takes place on day 5
     

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Decidua capsularis and Decidua basalis
Decidua capsularis and Decidua parietalis
Decidua basalis and Decidua parietalis
Decidua parietalis and Decidua Vera

questions.text: A 21 y primigravida presents at 6 weeks. An ultrasound reveals the following image showing an intra-uterine gestational sac. The double decidual sac sign is demonstrated. This sign is formed by which 2 layers of the decidua?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis

 

Explanation:

 

  • After implantation, the decidua (thickened endometrium of pregnancy) is differentiated into 3 parts
     
  1. Decidua basalis
    • Portion of the decidua which lies between the embryo and the muscular wall of the uterus
    • Forms the site of attachment of the placenta
  2. Decidua capsularis
    • Portion of decidua which intervenes between the embryo and the uterine cavity
  3. Decidua parietalis (aka Decidua vera)
    • Portion of decidua not related to the site of implantation, but lines the rest of the uterine cavity
       

 

  • The double decidual sac sign seen on the ultrasound is formed by the Decidua parietalis and the Decidua capsularis
     

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The double decidual sac sign seen on the ultrasound is formed by the Decidua parietalis and the Decidua capsularis
     

 

Ref: Page no 159, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 22, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetric 9th edition

choices.text: Formation of acrosome

questions.text: Spermiogenesis includes all the following components except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Sperm capacitation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Spermiogenesis is the process of conversion of spherical spermatids into longitudinal spermatozoa without any change in chromosome number (haploid).
  • It consists of the following:
    • Formation of acrosome
    • Formation of neck, middle piece and tail
    • Nuclear condensation
    • Shedding of most of the cytoplasm
  • Sperm capacitation is the physiological change in which the sperm becomes hyper motile and is able to bind and fertilize a secondary oocyte. This occurs in the fallopian tube.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spermiogenesis is the process of conversion of spherical spermatids into longitudinal spermatozoa without any change in chromosome number (haploid).
  • It consists of the following:
    • Formation of acrosome
    • Formation of neck, middle piece and tail
    • Nuclear condensation
    • Shedding of most of the cytoplasm

 

Ref: Page no 17, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

questions.text: At what stage of the cell cycle are primary oocytes arrested?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Prophase 1

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the fetal female gonads, the germ cells multiply by mitosis to differentiate into oogonia
  • Max oogonia are at the 20th week of fetal life (7 million)
    • These reduce (by atresia and apoptosis) to 1-2 million at birth
    • 300-400,000 at puberty
    • 100 at menopause
    • Only 400-500 primary oocytes are likely to ovulate during the reproductive life of a woman
  • The oogonia enter meiosis to form the primary oocyte which rest in the diplotene phase of prophase 1 until puberty

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In the fetal female gonads, the germ cells multiply by mitosis to differentiate into oogonia
  • Max oogonia are at the 20th week of fetal life (7 million)
    • These reduce (by atresia and apoptosis) to 1-2 million at birth
    • 300-400,000 at puberty
    • 100 at menopause
    • Only 400-500 primary oocytes are likely to ovulate during the reproductive life of a woman
  • The oogonia enter meiosis to form the primary oocyte which rest in the diplotene phase of prophase 1 until puberty

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: All are steps in implantation of the zygote except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cleavage

 

Explanation:

 

  • Implantation is the process by which the blastocyst penetrates the uterine mucosa to get implanted in the endometrium
  • It starts on the 6th day of ovulation (20th day of LMP)
  • It involves 4 steps
    1. Apposition
    2. Adhesion
    3. Penetration
    4. Invasion
  • Cleavage refers to the sub-division of the fertilized ovum into smaller cells

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Implantation is the process by which the blastocyst penetrates the uterine mucosa to get implanted in the endometrium
  • It starts on the 6th day of ovulation (20th day of LMP)
  • It involves 4 steps
    1. Apposition
    2. Adhesion
    3. Penetration
    4. Invasion

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: Cleavage of the zygote to the 2-cell stage is reached how many hours after fertilization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 30

 

Explanation:

 

  • The 2-cell stage is reached approximately 30 hours after fertilization
  • Each contains equal cytoplasmic volume and chromosome numbers
  • Cleavage continues into the 4,8,16 cell stage until a cluster of cells called a ‘morula’ is formed
  • On the 4th day, the morula enters the uterine cavity (16-64 cell stage)
  • Blastocyst formation occurs on the 5th day
  • Implantation occurs on the 6th day (corresponds to the 20th day of a regular menstrual cycle)
     

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The 2-cell stage is reached approximately 30 hours after fertilization
  • Each contains equal cytoplasmic volume and chromosome numbers
  • Cleavage continues into the 4,8,16 cell stage until a cluster of cells called a ‘morula’ is formed
  • On the 4th day, the morula enters the uterine cavity (16-64 cell stage)
  • Blastocyst formation occurs on the 5th day
  • Implantation occurs on the 6th day (corresponds to the 20th day of a regular menstrual cycle)

 

Ref: Page no 19, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: A 32 year old woman is undergoing IVF-ET. After in-vitro fertilization, the following embryo has been decided to be transferred. On what day following fertilization, is this embryo seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Day 3

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a microscopic image of an 8-cell embryo which is seen on Day 3
  • Usually in IVF, a Day 3 embryo is transferred in the uterine cavity or a Day 5 (blastocyst) embryo is transferred in the uterine cavity.

 

Microscopic images of different cleavage stages

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Usually in IVF, a Day 3 embryo is transferred in the uterine cavity or a Day 5 (blastocyst) embryo is transferred in the uterine cavity.

 

Microscopic images of different cleavage stages

 

 

Ref: Page no 19, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Completion of the 2nd meiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation
The fertilizable life span of an oocyte is 12-24 hours and that of a sperm is 48 – 72 hours
Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm
Zona reaction prevents the entry of other sperms

questions.text: The incorrect statement regarding fertilization is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Completion of the 2nd meiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Completion of the 2nd meiotic division of the oocyte happens at ovulation: This is an incorrect statement. Completion of the 2nd meiotic division occurs at the time of fertilization resulting in a female pronucleus and the 2nd polar body.

 

Option B: The fertilizable life span of an oocyte is 12-24 hours and that of a sperm is 48 – 72 hours. This is correct. 

 

Option C: Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm. This is a correct statement. Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm. More than 1 sperm may penetrate the zona pellucida but soon after sperm fusion, penetration of other sperms is prevented by zona reaction (hardening) or oolemma block due to release of cortical granules by exocytosis from the oocyte.

 

Option D: Zona reaction prevents the entry of other sperms. This is also a correct statement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The fertilizable life span of an oocyte is 12-24 hours and that of a sperm is 48 – 72 hours
  • Penetration of the zona pellucida is facilitated by release of hyaluronidase from the acrosomal cap of the sperm. More than 1 sperm may penetrate the zona pellucida but soon after sperm fusion, penetration of other sperms is prevented by zona reaction (hardening) or oolemma block due to release of cortical granules by exocytosis from the oocyte.
  • Completion of the 2nd meiotic division occurs at the time of fertilization resulting in a female pronucleus and the 2nd polar body.

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Formation of two secondary oocytes
Formation of two polar bodies
Formation of one secondary oocyte and one polar body
Formation of two haploid ova

questions.text: In females, what is the outcome of meiosis I in oogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Formation of one secondary oocyte and one polar body

 

Explanation:

 

In females, meiosis I in oogenesis results in the formation of one secondary oocyte and one polar body. The secondary oocyte proceeds to meiosis II, while the polar body often disintegrates.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary oocyte gets arrested in prophase 1 of meiosis 1 and resumes only at puberty.
  • Meiosis 1 occurs at ovulation with the formation of a secondary oocyte and a polar body.
  • Meiosis 2 occurs at fertilization with the formation of zygote (fertilized oocyte) and the 2nd polar body.

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: After fertilization by a sperm

questions.text: During oogenesis, when is meiosis II completed in a female's reproductive system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. After fertilization by a sperm

 

Explanation:

 

Meiosis II in oogenesis is completed after fertilization by a sperm. Prior to fertilization, the secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II. Fertilization triggers the completion of meiosis II, resulting in a mature fertilized ovum (zygote) and a second polar body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary oocyte gets arrested in prophase 1 of meiosis 1 and resumes only at puberty
  • Meiosis 1 occurs at ovulation with the formation of a secondary oocyte and a polar body
  • Meiosis 2 occurs at fertilization with the formation of zygote (fertilized oocyte) and the 2nd polar body.

 

 

Ref: Page no 16, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: During which stage of embryonic development does implantation occur in the uterine wall?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blastocyst

 

Explanation:

 

Implantation occurs during the blastocyst stage of embryonic development. The blastocyst, a hollow structure, attaches to the uterine wall, beginning the process of pregnancy. Implantation begins on the 6th day (corresponds to the 20th day of a regular menstrual cycle) and is completed by the 10th- 11th day.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Implantation occurs at blastocyst stage.
  • Begins on the 6th day; complete by 10th day.

 

Ref: Page no 19, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition
